Description: In this case, which dragged on for more than a decade, the original verdict in the trial court awarded $3.8 million in damages to six women who alleged that they had been subjected to a sexually hostile work environment at a Ralphs store in Escondido, California. The trial judge threw out that award and ordered a new trial. In 2002 another jury awarded $30 million in punitive damages but the judge said that unless the plaintiffs accepted a lower amount he would order a new trial. Two of the six plaintiffs accepted a total of $4.5 million in punitives plus the $300,000 they had been awarded in compensatory damages. In 2006 a state appeals court ruled that the damages for the other plaintiffs should be six times their $250,000 in compensatory damages, which amounted to a total of $1.75 million.
Court: Superior Court of State of California, County of San Diego
Info Source: https://www.courtlistener.com/opinion/2255642/gober-v-ralphs-grocery-co/
https://www.pacermonitor.com/public/case/4061709/Thome_v_Roundys_Supermarkets,_Inc

Description: King Soopers, City Market, and their parent company, Kroger, agreed to pay a record $7 million settlement for systemic violations of the Controlled Substances Act by the company's pharmacies. In addition to the penalty, Kroger agreed to implement a pharmacy compliance program estimated to cost over $6 million dollars in all 1,900 of its pharmacies nationwide.
Info Source: KING SOOPERS AGREES TO PAY RECORD AMOUNT FOR VIOLATIONS OF CONTROLLED SUBSTANCES ACT, US Fed News, October 21, 2005 (via Nexis).
